Posts.Content: Hi Jo, just picked up your post.  Well done for going for a positive attitude.  I'mreally lucky that I am a naturally positive person (nickname at work was Pollyanna!) and although it does drive other people mad from time to time it's really helped me get through this.  Despite being the way I am I do get bad days (who doesn't with this foul disease) I try to think of the funny things that have happened during the last 11 months - like the old lady who wandered into my room in the convalescent home by mistake.  Gave her quite a shock when I spoke to her.  She didn't answer, I just got a glare, but just as she was leaving she turned round and asked quite seriously "have you got any cake?".  It still makes laugh months later!  Why was I in a convalescent home?  My husband has COPD and mild Asperges syndrome so he couldn't look after me after surgery.  He didn't do much during chemo and radiotherapy either but that's another story!   I can promise you the more you try to be positive the better you'll feel in yourself and the bad days will hopefully get easier to cope with.  The very,very best of luck, have a wonderful Christmas with your family, try to laugh as much as you can and you ARE going to get through this.  Loads of love and huge virtual hugs, keep in touch
Posts.Title: New day, new attitude

Posts.Content: Hi GrandmaStar, first of all congratulations on your new greatgrandson!  I adore mine - he's just coming up to four and is utterly adorable. I had palpitations and breathlessness and a constant feeling of weakness.  Mine turned out to be low potassium so it might be worth asking if your next blood test could include that. Best of luck with your next tests, appointments etc, love and hugs
Posts.Title: Palpitations / GreatGrandson / Herceptin

Posts.Content: I lived on caramel ice cream, scrambled egg and refreshers (fizzy sweets) as they were the only things I could taste that didn't make me nauseous.  I drank flat lemonade, I went right off tea, coffee and hot chocolate but did have orange juice every morning. Kacang is absolutely right about the mouthwash, mine was prescribed so I didn't have to find a recipe.  Good luck with finding the right solution for you, love and hugs
Posts.Title: Oh my mouth...

Posts.Content: Hi Ladies (and any gents reading this thread!) I too had low potassium, so bad at one point the lab rang me for my pharmacy address & telephone number the same day as the blood test so that they could email the pharmacy with the prescription!  My symptoms though were breathlessness and a rapid heart rate every time I did anything more strenuous than sitting down!  Fine now though but will need another blood test to confirm.   As far as crying goes I wept for ages after an episode of "Say Yes the Dress" and cried for hours when my husband came home quarter of an hour late from having a glass of wine in our local bar with a couple of his friends!    I'm the kind of person who wells up during parades, listening to a children's choir and watching animal programmes but I haven't been really emotional during my treatment although I expected to be. We're definitely all different!  Love and hugs
Posts.Title: Over Emotional....

Posts.Content: Wonderful news, such a relief! Love and hugs
Posts.Title: The results are in!

Posts.Content: Hi all, I'm on week 3 of radiotherapy and our flu jab letters arrived last week.  The nurse arrived the same day to do a blood test for low potassium.  He said no problems with the flu jab but as I had really nasty flu-like symptoms with T I should wait until the beginning of November to have the flu jab.  I finish radiotherapy on 26 October.  Looks like once again we're all different! Love and hugs xxx
Posts.Title: Flu jabs?

Posts.Content: Hi Wombat, You are just 4 weeks after surgery and you'll get aches and pains everywhere but I'm glad you've got an appointment so you can get it checked out and reassure yourself.  Pain is so very debilitating and if you don't know what's causing it it'll make you depressed too.   My husband has COPD, diabetes and mild Asperges syndrome so he was pretty useless during my treatment.  In fact when I asked him how he felt he said he was glad it wasn't him!   Although he seemed less than sympathetic with me, he obviously took it all in as he spent ages telling his friends how much I was suffering.  He cannot empathise with others so although he knew I was suffering he couldn't understand how I felt or what my needs were. Try to be patient with your husband, he's probably completely bewildered by the whole thing and doesn't really know how to cope with how you're feeling.  He probably feels pretty helpless too.  Ask him to explain how he feels (without getting cross if you can!) and try to be sympathetic although you're hurting so much.  He might need a bit of reassurance so perhaps he could go to one of your appointments with you so that he can understand what's happening a bit better Remember we're here whenever you need to let off steam, and fingers crossed and loads of good luck for your appointment.  Love and hugs
Posts.Title: upper back pain

Posts.Content: I agree with Julia, we can't take a healthy future for granted but we can try to be positive about it.  Don't knock the smilers, I'm really not sure where you get the idea that they are either fake, insensitive or not very bright.  We all have emotional issues but some of us try to put a good face on it and try to see the positive side - believe me it's bl**dy hard sometimes.  I'm afraid your comments upset me a bit but as you say, this is the one place where you can state your own truth and you have every right to state your opinion! Love and hugs
Posts.Title: Why ?

Posts.Content: Have a wonderful day on Sunday and very best wishes for a great future together love and hugs
Posts.Title: Good News Story for a cold Tuesday

Posts.Content: Hi Carolyn   thank goodness someone else feels as unmotivated as I do.  I thought I was just being lazy and I do feel that if I tried to explain it to anyone they would think I'm "putting it on".  I've tried so hard to be positive and cheerful throughout this and I still have 19 radiotherapy sessions to go.  So far I feel as though it's all an unpleasant dream that I'm floating through and one day I'll wake up and just be me again but every time I look in the mirror I know it's not.  Is this feeling normal?  I haven't had any of the shock or scared feelings that most seem to have and I've only had a good cry twice, both in week 2 of T.  Iwonder if this is a normal reaction to what's happening to me.  Still, I'll carry on being positive, at least when I'm with other people and try not to bore them too much and also try not to think too much about the future (although every little twinge makes me wonder if it's coming back!   Karen (Lacomtekp) and I will be meeting up soon so I'm really looking forward to that!   Love and hugs
Posts.Title: Why ?

Posts.Content: We'll definitely have fun!  So sorry you can't be with us but next time you're in France perhaps the three of us could meet? lol:)) Love & hugs Wendy xxx PS Karen, I finish my treatment on 26 Oct - perhaps the following week?  xxx
Posts.Title: Why ?

Posts.Content: Hi London, so glad you've come through today okay but I know the wait for results will be awful.  We're all here for. you so have a rant, a cry or just want a bit of comfort we'll be listening.  I wish I could give you a real hug but here's some virtual ones to tide you over ((((((((((((O)))))))))))).  Gros bisous, Je t'embrasse P.S. I'm in Cardiff visiting my daughter and her family from 22 February to 7 March - whereabouts are you? xx
Posts.Title: Have to be honest.....

Posts.Content: Hi London, hope you're feeling a bit better tonight, not quite so sore I hope. You've had a rough couple of weeks and a difficult day yesterday and I really feel for you, my heart goes out to you.  I would love to send you one of my handmade cards to cheer you up  (just getting back into it after a year of treatment) but as I can't loads of love and ((((((((((very gentle hugs)))))))))),
Posts.Title: Have to be honest.....

Posts.Content: Oh dear, little Wombat, you've had such a horrible time.  I do hope that it's really worked though and that they start looking after you properly.  Just remember you deserve to be treated with a bit of thought, you deserve to have lots of TLC, hugs and little treats.  My husband was useless while I was going through chemo but now I've nearly finished radiotherapy he's become a lot more thoughtful - maybe it's because I too had a couple of meltdowns.  He took me out for supper tonight so that I wouldn't have to cook!  Nothing much you might think but he has mild Asperges syndrome so getting through to him has been hard.  The very best of good luck with your family from now on, keep in touch and lots of virtual hugs, love Wendy xxx P.S. hope they get you some Toffifee!
Posts.Title: Why ?

Posts.Content: Hi Dulcie, of course you didn't mean to upset anyone.  I suppose I'm a bit over sensitive now and I too hate the "positive" brigade particularly those who've never had cancer but think that by constantly using encouraging words and phrases they're helping.  They're not but I don't want sympathy either.  My lovely neighbour, who's been an absolute brick during all of this, keeps telling me that I'm "nearly there" and I should be happy.  I KNOW that!  But it doesn't help in the wee small hours when you start worrying and it especially doesn't help when I'm feeling low.  She's been so brilliant coming to all my appointments with me, driving me everywhere and sitting with me during chemo, I don't have the heart to ask her to shut up!  I'm lucky in that I'm a naturally positive person but nobody can be positive all the time can they?  I'm also a very sensitive one, just good at hiding it, especially from my family but I've begun to at least tell them what I'm actually going through, but as I'm trying to stay cheerful they think I'm brave - I'm not, just trying hard. It sounds as though you're getting help with the way you feel, and your consultant understands PTSD - I don't think most people realise that cancer is a hugely life-changing experience. Good luck with your future,  Love and hugs
Posts.Title: Why ?

Posts.Content: Hi London, so glad you've come through today okay but I know the wait for results will be awful.  We're all here for. you so have a rant, a cry or just want a bit of comfort we'll be listening.  I wish I could give you a real hug but here's some virtual ones to tide you over ((((((((((((O)))))))))))).  Gros bisous, Je t'embrasse P.S. I'm in Cardiff visiting my daughter and her family from 22 February to 7 March - whereabouts are you? xx
Posts.Title: Have to be honest.....

Posts.Content: Hi London, you've been an absolute brick for everyone else, now it's your turn to be supported by all your colleagues on here.  Hope your appointment goes well on Wednesday, I'll be thinking of you.  Loads of virtual hugs, (((((((O))))))) lots of love
Posts.Title: Have to be honest.....

Posts.Content: Hi London, hope you're feeling a bit better tonight, not quite so sore I hope. You've had a rough couple of weeks and a difficult day yesterday and I really feel for you, my heart goes out to you.  I would love to send you one of my handmade cards to cheer you up  (just getting back into it after a year of treatment) but as I can't loads of love and ((((((((((very gentle hugs)))))))))),
Posts.Title: Have to be honest.....

Posts.Content: Hi London, can't sleep as usual.  Thinking of you having your appointment tomorrow and just wanted to wish you luck, hold your hand (virtually!) and send you loads of ((((((((((virtual hugs)))))))))) Lots of love
Posts.Title: Have to be honest.....

Posts.Content: Hi aculuz65, thanks for replying so quickly.  I will mention it to my team & see what they suggest, love and hugs
Posts.Title: Peripheral neuropathy

Posts.Content: Hi, I have developed numbness in both hands a few minutes after starting to use the computer mouse and other repetitive jobs.   It's been going on for around 3 months now but I finished chemo last August, rads in December and I'm now on letrazole.  Due to see my surgeon to discuss possible reconstruction of missing boob and reduction of remaining (huge) boob Mon 25 July.  Should I mention it or should I wait for my onco appointment on 10 August?  Not sure if it's important enough to mention at all.  Any advice much appreciated!  Love and hugs xx
Posts.Title: Peripheral neuropathy

Posts.Content: Hi, I have developed numbness in both hands a few minutes after starting to use the computer mouse and other repetitive jobs.   It's been going on for around 3 months now but I finished chemo last August, rads in December and I'm now on letrazole.  Due to see my surgeon to discuss possible reconstruction of missing boob and reduction of remaining (huge) boob Mon 25 July.  Should I mention it or should I wait for my onco appointment on 10 August?  Not sure if it's important enough to mention at all.  Any advice much appreciated!  Love and hugs xx
Posts.Title: Peripheral neuropathy

Posts.Content: Hi aculuz65, thanks for replying so quickly.  I will mention it to my team & see what they suggest, love and hugs
Posts.Title: Peripheral neuropathy

Posts.Content: Animals do seem to understand more than we might think.  I have two part feral cats, now 3 years old.  One, Rosie, is lap cat especially when the weather isn't too good.  Her sister, Bunty, likes to be near me me but is definitely not a lap cat.  Since starting chemo Bunty's behaviour has changed.  She's now extremely loving, wanting to be picked up and cuddled all the time and standing or lying on my chest when I'm lying down (quite a lot over the last 18 weeks lol!) and purring like mad!  Very comforting but not very comfortable when she stands on my scar!  Still, I don't push her away as it's so lovely to have this experience with her.  I'm convinced she knows I'm not too well and is helping in her own way. So very glad your first post wasn't right, I couldn't imagine how you would cope with shrinkage of over a foot!  Thank goodness it's 'only' a few inches, although that must be difficult enough. Hope you get lots of help on the other forum but don't forget we're here for you on this one too if you ever need a chat.  Big virtual hugs, lots of love,
Posts.Title: Physical changes .

Posts.Content: thanks Carol, I've got a couple of older Bravissimo bras so I'll have a go with one of those!  Love and hugs
Posts.Title: Bras - rant!!!!

Posts.Content: Thanks so much for the link to Asda - I'll be going over to the UK in Feb for my great grandson's 4th birthday and I've seen a very pretty pale blue PS bra at £8.  For that price it's worth sending for one in advance and trying it isn't it!  My main problem is that my breasts (only one left now!) are very heavy and it took me years to find proper supporting bras that didn't give me back ache.  They're underwired from Bravissimo and they're lovely but of course I can't wear them now and Bravissimo don't do PS bras and only have a tiny range of non-wired bras (about 3!).  I've bought a couple of Triumph Doreen bras in my size (38G) but because of the weight I need to constantly adjust the real one.  Funnily enough the prosthesis, which is a silicone one to balance the heavy real one, doesn't need adjusting at all!  When can we wear underwired again - or is it never? :(( Love and hugs
Posts.Title: Bras - rant!!!!

Posts.Content: Hi Jo, With FEC my mouth tasted horrible but I was prescribed a bicarb/Eludril mouthwash and it did help.  I couldn't taste most things, water tasted foul, couldn't drink my usual myriad cups of tea, and wine and coffee were just like drinking acid!  I ate anyway but much smaller quantities as everything tasted like cardboard except Carte d'Or caramel ice cream (other brands tasted "wrong") which I ate loads of.  Also ordinary lemonade left to go flat helped with any nausea.  With T I continued the mouthwash but despite using it around 5 times a day I still got oral thrush at the beginning of week 2 of each cycle.  Only lasted a few days though as the mouthwash really does help.  I finished chemo at the end of August and rads at the end of October and my taste buds are much better.  Most things taste okay but some things are still a bit tasteless although I can drink coffee now and I am now having the odd glass of wine.  So you will get through this without too much hassle and it'll all be worth it in the end!  Just remember you have to eat to keep your strength up even if you aren't hungry, and drink lots to help flush the chemo through your system.  Good luck with your treatment, the time will go surprisingly quickly and we're all here for you when you need us Love and hugs
Posts.Title: Chemotherapy & vile chemical taste in mouth

Posts.Content: Hi Londonlass Just a quick note to wish you all the best for Monday, try to relax and enjoy the weekend.  Thinking of you, big virtual hug, xxx
Posts.Title: So now my BCN is lying to my face...............

Posts.Content: Hi Myshittit, absolutely love your username!  So appropriate, wish I'd thought of it!  If you can manage it try eating stewed plums, apricots and rhubarb for pudding after your evening meal.  For me,cold from the fridge was best as eating anything hot was horrible!  I lived on caramel ice cream (only thing I could taste!) and flat lemonade for ages but the occasional scrambled egg was nice, it didn't taste of anything but it was lovely and smooth in my mouth.  Sounds like you are doing all the right things, remember to keep hydrated, it will help and use the mouthwash before and after eating and before you go to bed after you've cleaned your teeth.  You sound really positive too which I believe also helps a lot.  You'll be surprised at how fast the time seems to have gone once it's all over! Any time you want a chat come and talk to us, there's always someone awake day or night. Love and hugs
Posts.Title: FEC side effect remedies needed please!!!!

Posts.Content: Hi All, it's a while since I've posted but when I saw this thread I just had to respond.  All my friends think I must be fine now and doing all the things I used to do, they seem to think I'm exaggerating when I try to explain how tired I get.  The joint pain is pretty miserable at times too but because I try to put on a brave face I must be back to normal!  I've just spent two lovely weeks in the UK with my son and his family but my son thinks I must be fine now and my daughter in law isn't remotely interested.  Still, my motto is keep positive and my new theme song is "I'm still standing"!  Love and supporting hugs with extra Welsh cwtchs to you all  Wendy xxx P.S. I finished surgery, chemo and radiotherapy last December and I'm now on 5 years letrazole - only 4 years and 3 months left to go!  Appointment with plastic surgeon next Tuesday to discuss reconstruction and reduction of ginormous remaining boob.  Can't wait to get a C cup after living with one flat side and a G cup the other!  Hope the new ones match each other! xx
Posts.Title: Annoyed!!!!!

Posts.Content: It made me laugh too!  40-odd years ago I had a hysterectomy and when I went to see my GP afterwards for the six week check up I asked whether I would continue to need smear tests.  He grinned and said "only if you want me to smear your tonsils"!  I live in France and there doesn't seem to be much in the way of modesty.  For my MRI scan I had a paper gown that opened at the front but the Dr and his male assistant didn't even notice.  I suppose they've seen it all before!  For the op I had a paper gown, delightful paper knickers and a fetching paper hat and was wheeled in my bed down to theatre where they lifted me straight on to the operating table.  A bit scary looking up at all those huge lights but the surgeon came over and shook my hand, said "don't worry" in french and the next thing I knew I was in recovery, minus boob, gown and hat, but plus paper knickers, with a handsome young male nurse encouraging me to wake up!  I've still got my operation stockings, you never know when you might need them! Good luck for your op, it's soon over and you'll be fine! Love and hugs
Posts.Title: Modesty during surgery

Posts.Content: Hi, I'm on day 8 tomorrow of 30 sessions of radiotherapy and no real problems.  I have a prescribed hyaluronic cream which is great.  The only pain I get is slight muscular pain where I used to have a left boob but this is due to keeping my arms above my head and it goes as soon as I lower my arms.  I don't know what your bcn thought she was doing but you'll see from this forum that SEs from radiotherapy are rare.  Good luck and sending virtual big hugs, love
Posts.Title: Rads - Panic?

Posts.Content: Hi All, I too have a Portacath and no problems at all.  It was put in under general anaesthetic and apart from the clingfilm type plaster over it for 2 days after (I couldn't move my head without pain) it was fine.  I have an anaesthetic patch to put over it one hour before chemo so I don't even feel the needle go in.  I wasn't given a choice but I'm so glad I have this!  I understand it will be removed when all chemo treatment is finished, I think at the end of July. If a PICC line is offered I'd go for it but ask if you can have a Portacath if possible. Best of luck Love Wendy xx
Posts.Title: PICC Line - yes or no?

Posts.Content: If it can be posted to France I'd definitely like one please! Love and hugs
Posts.Title: Pandas

Posts.Content: Hi Jojo  everytime I went for chemo my BP was indeed sky high but they said that was normal as everyone is stressed and that puts your BP up.  For my first T I was really worried (unnecessarily as it turned out!)  and so I had a sedative drip as well as all the usual chemo stuff.  For all my chemos I dozed off halfway through and woke up when they brought lunch!  It's different in France I think as for every session you have a consultation with your onco  after you've seen the nurse & before you start the day's chemo - she gives the chemo nurses a dossier giving details of the dose I'll need for that session.  You get to read that while they're putting the tubes in but not being a medical person it didn't mean much - it did say how long each "bag" would take but you can ask about that if you're worried.  Honestly, it's nowhere near as scary as you think it's going to be and not everybody gets all the side effects.  Ask for Emend to combat sickness, it really does work and drink lots of water;  Don't feel guilty if you don't have the energy to do all the things you think you ought to be doing, just take it as easily as you can and rest whenever possible.  Good luck, you'll be surprised at how soon all your treatment is finished and you're on the home straight.  Thinking of you tomorrow, love and big virtual hugs
Posts.Title: Appointment cancelled

Posts.Content: Hi Jojo  everytime I went for chemo my BP was indeed sky high but they said that was normal as everyone is stressed and that puts your BP up.  For my first T I was really worried (unnecessarily as it turned out!)  and so I had a sedative drip as well as all the usual chemo stuff.  For all my chemos I dozed off halfway through and woke up when they brought lunch!  It's different in France I think as for every session you have a consultation with your onco  after you've seen the nurse & before you start the day's chemo - she gives the chemo nurses a dossier giving details of the dose I'll need for that session.  You get to read that while they're putting the tubes in but not being a medical person it didn't mean much - it did say how long each "bag" would take but you can ask about that if you're worried.  Honestly, it's nowhere near as scary as you think it's going to be and not everybody gets all the side effects.  Ask for Emend to combat sickness, it really does work and drink lots of water;  Don't feel guilty if you don't have the energy to do all the things you think you ought to be doing, just take it as easily as you can and rest whenever possible.  Good luck, you'll be surprised at how soon all your treatment is finished and you're on the home straight.  Thinking of you tomorrow, love and big virtual hugs
Posts.Title: Appointment cancelled

Posts.Content: Hi London, I'm so pleased for you, what a huge weight off your mind!  Thinking of you being able to enjoy your life now without the hassle of extra treaments, yay!!!  Love and hugs
Posts.Title: Feeling in control...........

Posts.Content: Hear hear!!!  Love and hugs
Posts.Title: Feeling in control...........

Posts.Content: Hi Momo, try not to worry (although it'll be on your mind all the time I know).  Sending a huge ((((((hug)))))) Love and hugs
Posts.Title: Just when I was trying to get back to normal

Posts.Content: Me too, I didn't connect it with letrazole til now  but I cleared the last one with gallons of liquid but I will mention at my next GP appointment.  Being on this forum is a godsend, so many things where I thought I was on my own!  For example, not just the UTI but a thread the other day about excessive tiredness before diagnosis, I thought it was just me!  Thanks Ladies!   Love and hugs
Posts.Title: Letrozole and UTI

Posts.Content: Hi Sue62, having had steroids for years with asthma and I never had any side effects so the steroids with chemo didn't bother me but I did get really bad shakes and trembling, so bad sometimes I couldn't stand up!  It turned out to be low potassium and low magnesium.  It might be worth asking them to check when you have your next blood test.  I live in France and they certainly took it seriously as the laboratory actually rang me at home to say they had emailed my pharmacy so my husband could collect the prescription immediately but that was just for the potassium as you can't have treatment for both at the same time.  After both treatments the shaking and trembling stopped and my heartbeat went back to normal.  Good luck with the rest of your treatment, hope everything goes well for you.  I agree, having the shakes when trying to inject can't be any fun!  Love and hugs
Posts.Title: Shakes and tears

Posts.Content: Hi all, it's a long time since I posted but I had a breast reduction last November with the first stage of a reconstruction of what used to be my left breast using Lipomodelage where they use liposuction to get fat from the stomach area and inject it into the mastectomy site.  Nearly 4 months later the injected area is still red and very hot and rock hard.  I saw my oncologist last Thursday (he didn't do the operation) and he wasn't at all happy.  He has ordered a scan, blood test and ultrasound and I'm to ring him as soon as it's been done.  He has also changed my hormone therapy from letrazole to tamoxifen but has not said why.  Has this happened to anyone else and should I be worried?  Grateful for any advice please!  Love and hugs PS hope everyone is doing okay
Posts.Title: Lipomodelage

Posts.Content: Hi All, I've had a single mastectomy, left side, and I've been told I can have a reconstruction and a breast reduction in about 18 months time.  However, I'm 72 years young and I have a large (38G) and very heavy breast left on the right hand side.  I cannot see that they would be able to stop my real breast from hanging down to my waist as it does at the moment even if it's a bit smaller, after all they're not plastic surgeons although they're pretty good at what they do!  I didn't like my boobs before as I'm small (5 foot nothing) and really big boobs look ridiculous apart from the backache, neck ache and round shoulders.  So I'm seriously thinking about a second mastectomy and then I can choose the size of my boobs - about a 38C I think.  At least I'll be able to wear clothes that actually fit me all over!  I just hope it's free in France - the reconstruction and reduction would be so I'm going to ask at my next appointment with my surgeon Love and hugs Wendy xxx
Posts.Title: is double mastectomy easier than prosthesis 24/7

Posts.Content: Hi All,  This is probably a really stupid question but chemo destroys your immune system right?  So if you no longer have the antibodies that you used to have against measles, chicken pox and goodness knows what else, when you get the white cells working properly again are you at risk from catching stuff that you thought you were immune against?  Daft I know but it just struck me the other day. Love Wendy xxx
Posts.Title: Antibodies

Posts.Content: Hi Gill Thanks so much for answering my question, it doesn't seem quite so daft now!  Very reassuring as I just have had ordinary cancer and didn't need stem cell treatment.  Still got 3 more goes of  T to go so I'll have to be careful for a while yet.   My next door neighbour's Dad has been staying with her but she has had to stay away from me as he has shingles.  Now he's gone home but it looks like she might have it too.  She has been wonderful during my treatment but now she needs me and I can't help her, only supportive phone calls.  I'm hoping that she feels much better soon as shingles is so miserable - with a bit of luck it's just a nasty cold and not shingles at all. I do hope your husband is on the mend now. Love Wendy xxx
Posts.Title: Antibodies

Posts.Content: Hi Vicky9989, welcome to the club that no-one wants to join but, having said that, I'm so glad you have.  Never feel afraid to come on here, there's always someone to talk to, day or night, we're always here.  Please DON'T GOOGLE!  Dr Google will scare you unnecessarily, any questions you have ask the ladies (and a few gents!) on here!  There are MacMillan Champions here who will be able to give really good and accurate advice and who've also been through what you are experiencing now.  I don't  have any medical training myself so I'm not a champion but I've been through a mastectomy, chemo, radiotherapy and I'm now on hormone therapy, I'm still here, still upbeat and I'm planning to live to 100!  As others have already said, the waiting really is the worst bit, it seems never ending and I can understand how desperately worried you are, especially with 2 young daughters to care for.  Try to keep as positive as you can, make plans for days out during the school holidays and please remember that it may be no more than a cyst.  Very best of luck, loads of ((((((((((supportive Welsh cwtchs))))))))) and please let us know your results!  Love and hugs
Posts.Title: Waiting on scan for lump in left breast, worried sick.

Posts.Content: Thanks Carolyn, I certainly will!  Love Wendy xxx
Posts.Title: Antibodies

Posts.Content: Wishing you all a wonderful Christmas - and a much better 2017!  Love and hugs
Posts.Title: Merry Christmas Everyone :)

Posts.Content: Oh, well done Karen!  So very glad your news was so brilliant.  That coffee may well turn into a celebratory wine!  Thanks for the friend request, I have, of course, accepted.  I was wondering how to keep in touch & now it'll be easy! Love Wendy xxx
Posts.Title: Taxotere.........please stop panicking!

Posts.Content: Thanks so much Karen, as you know I've just had my 1st T (next one on 25 July) and I was so worried about side effects beforehand, unnecessarily as it turned out.  Yes, I have had (and am still having) fatigue, some joint pain (mostly at night) and a very nasty mouth despite the bicarb/elodril mouthwash but none of it has been unbearable.  So please, ladies don't panic it certainly wasn't as bad as I though it was going to be. Coffee after it's all over in Jonzac or Pons would be great Karen.  I'll make sure I keep in touch Love Wendy xxx
Posts.Title: Taxotere.........please stop panicking!

Posts.Content: Mine were fine until about a month after I finished chemo, then they went yellow and began to get nasty ridges.  I used Evonail throughout chemo and my nails were lovely!  Should have known there's not much you can get away with!   I kept my nails short and filed as each ridge fell off.  Anyway, 6 months after the last dose of T my nails now look reasonable and I've just bought a pretty nail varnish that I hope will stop them being so brittle.  Fingers crossed! Love and hugs
Posts.Title: Nails on 'T'

Posts.Content: Hi, I had a Portacath in and had absolutely no problems with being given chemo (the SEs were a different matter!)  Ports seem to be the norm in France and they prescribe an anaesthetic patch to put on an hour before chemo so you genuinely don't feel a thing.  I've now had my last radiotherapy and I've been told I will be keeping my port for the next 2 years just in case.  As I don't notice it at all that's no problem.  If they offer a PICC line, or better still, a port, go for it.  It's much easier on your veins and it surely must be easier on the nurses too as they don't have to keep searching for fresh places to stick the canula! Very best of luck with your treatment, we're all here for you when you don't feel so good, but it's all doable and you'll feel so proud of yourself self at the end!  Love and hugs Very best of luck with your treatment
Posts.Title: Chemo every week for 12 weeks Taxol

Posts.Content: Hi Snowy's Mum, what wonderful news!  Onward and upward, have a wonderful Christmas love and hugs xxx
Posts.Title: Normal MRI scan

Posts.Content: While I was having T I was given big ice bands to wear on my feet and ankles during treatment.  This seems to be standard treatment in France.   It must have helped as my nails were lovely until about a month after chemo finished.  See my email above for what happened next!
Posts.Title: Nails on 'T'

Posts.Content: Sorry, meant wrists and ankles - chemo brain again!
Posts.Title: Nails on 'T'

Posts.Content: Hi London, so sorry to hear about your back but very glad it's not affecting your baby lifting!  I have really miserable backache but different from yours in that mine is worse when walking or standing or sitting in certain types of chair.  I find a straight backed chair eases it somewhat and if it's not straight enough I add a cushion in the small of my back.  I take both paracetamol and voltarol (but try to restrict it to when I get up and just before bedtime).  Try a cushion when sitting down and when you lie down in bed and a hot water bottle but you could see your GP and get a support brace which my neighbour uses with great success  Not sure any of this will help but very best of luck with finding a solution, you've been through so much already you don't need this on top!  Thinking of you, love and an extra big cwtch (a very special welsh hug!)
Posts.Title: Ideas on coping with backache....

Posts.Content: Hi, I too have had really bad stomach cramps and diarrhoea with T.  I took the advice given me on this site (what a godsend this site is!) and took Imodium, feeling so much better now.  After talking to Karen P I realised I wasn't eating or drinking enough so no wonder things weren't working properly.  Do hope you feel better soon.  Love and hugs
Posts.Title: overactive bowel

Posts.Content: Well said Elaine!  This time last year I was in blissful ignorance that I had BC - this year here I am, having had an horrendous year but I'm through it (,except for SEs from letrazole!) and feeling fine (most of the time anyway!).  I'm so glad I joined the BC club, it's been a lifeline and really helpful on the down days. Happy Christmas everyone and best wishes for a healthier new year.  Love and hugs
Posts.Title: Christmas reflection

Posts.Content: Hi, I had shortness of breath during 2nd dose of T but as I'm asthmatic I didn't do anything about it until next T when it was much worse. By then though my GP had put me on potassium pills as my blood test showed it was very low.  This can cause breathlessness, fatigue and increased pulse rate so it might be that.  Worth getting it checked.  Love and hugs
Posts.Title: Short of breath

Posts.Content: Hi Snowy's Mum, what wonderful news, I'm so happy for you!  Love and hugs xxx
Posts.Title: 1st Annual mammo clear.....I am so happy

Posts.Content: Hi Jenny1973 I had 5 separate tumours in my left breast so I was given a mastectomy with removal of 11 lymph nodes.  I was ER+ and HER2-.  All 5 of the tumours were cancerous and 3 lymphs so my surgeon explained that it was safer for me to have had all of them removed to avoid the risk of the cancer coming back.  She also explained that I would be able to have a recon later on with a breast reduction of my right breast as my breasts are (were!)  very large & heavy. I'm really looking forward to having a smaller bust perhaps a D cup instead of the G I have now!   I must admit I don't know an awful lot about this but I felt relieved that the recon will come later as I'm scared of the cancer coming back in the same area (although I know it's unlikely) and any resulting op affecting the recon.  I think you should discuss your fears with your surgeon, they are really helpful, they really don't want you to feel any more anxious or upset than necessary.  I am having chemo 3 x FEC followed by 3 x Taxotere then radiotherapy.  Yes it's cr*p but better than the alternative! Very best of luck and Bon Courage as they say here! Love Wendy xx
Posts.Title: waiting for mastectomy and sentinel node biopsy - what about reconstruction...

Posts.Content: Well done Lynn, you deserve a medal!  Wonderful news that it's finally done.  Loads of love and best wishes for your new future :))  Love and hugs xxx
Posts.Title: Finished at last!!!!

Posts.Content: Merry Christmas everyone and a happy and healthy New year!  My lovely neighbour is coming to us for Christmas and she's doing the sprouts with lardons and walnuts - if she can get my husband to eat one without whinging it'll be a miracle!  Love, hugs and best wishes for as enjoyable a day as possible
Posts.Title: Xmas

Posts.Content: Thanks Kacang! xxx
Posts.Title: Curious.....

Posts.Content: Hi Lisab,  I started letrazole on 9 December last year so I've not been on it very long.  First couple of weeks no obvious SEs but I now have joint pain (not too bad except for one knee), UTIs (but not too frequent) .  Main SE for me is I'm back to overwhelming tiredness and sleeplessness but we're all different and I suspect that others have it much worse or much easier than I do!  Can't say about the benefits yet as I've got nearly 5 years to go - all I can be confident of is that this is going to help to keep the cancer from coming back!  Not much help I'm afraid but others may be able to give their experiences.  Love and hugs
Posts.Title: Curious.....

Posts.Content: Thanks Lisab, I did have a reasonably good night's sleep, woke up at 5am and couldn't get back so finished a novel I was reading!  Love and hugs
Posts.Title: Curious.....

Posts.Content: Hi all, Saw the plastic surgeon yesterday for a discussion about a reconstruction of my left ex-boob and a reduction of my ginormous right boob.  I've been given a number of options (all the docs are in French so I'll have to get someone to help me understand them) to consider.  I see him again in 15 days to tell him what I've decided.  The one thing I wasn't expecting was that the reduction would be done after the recon in a second op, maybe as much as 6 months later.  This is to allow the new boob to settle down in shape and look so he can get a good match with the reduction.  Anybody any advice 're the recon op, pain, recovery etc?  If I go for it, it will be with muscle from my stomach.  Love and hugs Wendy xxx
Posts.Title: Reconstruction and reduction

Posts.Content: Hi Lisab,  I started letrazole on 9 December last year so I've not been on it very long.  First couple of weeks no obvious SEs but I now have joint pain (not too bad except for one knee), UTIs (but not too frequent) .  Main SE for me is I'm back to overwhelming tiredness and sleeplessness but we're all different and I suspect that others have it much worse or much easier than I do!  Can't say about the benefits yet as I've got nearly 5 years to go - all I can be confident of is that this is going to help to keep the cancer from coming back!  Not much help I'm afraid but others may be able to give their experiences.  Love and hugs
Posts.Title: Curious.....

Posts.Content: Hi, I had 5 tumours, two big ones (I think the biggest one was around 22) and 3 little tiny ones that I didn't feel at all.  I only found the big one in the shower on a Wednesday but as I had a mammogram booked for the Friday I waited til then.  We get the results on the same day here, so I had the mammogram followed by an ultrasound (the clinic was actually closed for lunch but the Doctor and the radiographer stayed to do it) so I knew before I went home that they weren't happy and were pretty sure it was cancer.  They booked me in for a biopsy the following Friday and I got the result for that 10 days later by phone.  So I think in comparison as I didn't have  the dreadful time waiting I've been really lucky!  Good luck with your treatment,  mine is over now except for the letrazole, love and hugs
Posts.Title: Curious.....

Posts.Content: Thanks Kacang! xxx
Posts.Title: Curious.....

Posts.Content: Thanks Lisab, I did have a reasonably good night's sleep, woke up at 5am and couldn't get back so finished a novel I was reading!  Love and hugs
Posts.Title: Curious.....

Posts.Content: Hi Dreamthief I didn't know you were in Cardiff!  I'll be visiting my daughter in Llanedeyrn in February for a couple of weeks as my great grandson will be 4 - Tim,e goes by so quickly!  I lived in Cardiff (Cyncoed) for more than 30 years before moving to Bridgend and then France. Love and hugs
Posts.Title: From cancer to cross-country. A positive post.

Posts.Content: Thank you so much Nutmeg56, that's really helpful.  I think my op will be taking muscle from my stomach too and I'm not looking forward to the pain but I am looking forward to the end result!  Thank you as well to all the kind ladies who responded, it has helped.  Love and hugs
Posts.Title: Reconstruction and reduction

Posts.Content: Looking good Mike!  Congratulations on reaching another milestone in the post cancer journey.  Hope to be as well as you when I get to your stage - not that I'll be doing any running lol!  :))  Love and hugs (Still on radiotherapy for another week, after that,only way is up!)
Posts.Title: From cancer to cross-country. A positive post.

Posts.Content: Hi, I too live in France and had a port fitted.  I've had absolutely no problems with it, I've even had blood tests taken that way before chemo followed by a quick flush through by hand then chemo by infusion.  Painless and easy, sometimes I even fell asleep!  Like Lacomtek I had an anaesthetic patch to put on an hour before to make it completely painless.  If you're worried chat to your oncologist, there really is nothing to be scared of.  I've been told it's the rolls royce of methods to get chemo drugs into you! Good luck, lots of hugs
Posts.Title: EC chemo through a portacath

Posts.Content: Thanks Julia, that makes things a lot clearer.  Love
Posts.Title: Concerned about recent news

Posts.Content: I agree, the cost of cancer care is horrendous, I had 6 neulasta injections at 1000€ a time but I don't know what everything else costs although I do know the mastectomy would have been around 3000€ or more.  In France we get a certain amount free from "the Social" which we top up with medical insurance but here you don't need a medical for insurance like you seem to need in other countries but if you are on benefits or over a certain age treatment is free.  The French system is also creaking at the seams but we don't go to the doctor for every ache or sniffle as you pay 25€ each time you go.  You get most of it back but for most people it's too expensive to go for every little ailment so at least when you do have to go the queue are nowhere near as long as in the UK.  Of course I agree that savings have to be made but in the UK the layers of management, performance monitors  and target setters coupled with the amount of paperwork required these days could be cut drastically rather than cutting medical staff and hospital beds.  There's also self medication which would help and the drug companies should take some responsibility for rising costs.  I just didn't think you could do that with chemo but I understand now that with certain chemos you can. I'll get off my soapbox now!   Love and hugs
Posts.Title: Concerned about recent news

Posts.Content: Oh, London, I'm so very very pleased for you, what a relief after all your worry and sleepless nights.  Congratulations and millions of congratulatory cwtchs!!! love and hugs
Posts.Title: It doesn't get any easier.....

Posts.Content: P.S. sleep well tonight! xxxxxxx
Posts.Title: It doesn't get any easier.....

Posts.Content: Hi, first of all there are no silly questions!  I'm like Kacang, I always take my shoes off unless told beforehand to keep them on.  I had 30 sessions but kept my trousers and knickers on so I didn't feel too exposed.  I think I'd probably lost all sense of dignity by then anyway!  Good luck with your treatment, it'll soon be behind you, it's amazing how fast the time goes.  Love and hugs
Posts.Title: Silly radiotherapy question -

Posts.Content: Hi All, although my treatment is finished I was still very concerned about a news item on television the other day talking about saving money on the NHS.  The idea seems to be to get people to self administer chemo.  When I had mine I had a blood test 3 days before then when I got there I was weighed and blood pressure, temperature etc checked before every session and my chemo was delivered to my "station" in a sealed bag with my name on it.  My port was then flushed out before the nurse administered the stuff.  I can only assume that the news item was about a different kind of chemo?  I live in France so it doesn't really affect me but it still seems to not be a sensible way to save money.  Any comments ladies (and gents)?  Love and hugs
Posts.Title: Concerned about recent news

Posts.Content: What a beautiful dog!  She's gorgeous and I know just how loving and helpful animals can be.  My two semi feral cats were wonderful, so warm and loving when I was so poorly.  I'm so glad you've got your beautiful girl to support you.  Cwtchs to you both, love and hugs
Posts.Title: It doesn't get any easier.....

Posts.Content: Hi London, just a quick note to say good luck for tomorrow and hopefully your bcn will have at least some news for you.  It's cr*p that she can't give results but I suppose it's not her responsibility.  Anyway I'll be thinking of you tomorrow, love and loads of (((((((cwtchs)))))):
Posts.Title: It doesn't get any easier.....

Posts.Content: Well done Lou, such good news about your NON angina!! . Hang in there for the next steps, you've done brilliantly!  Love and hugs P.S. forgot to wish you good luck with your acid reflux test - it'll soon be out of the way and yet another box ticked! xxx
Posts.Title: Diagnosed with breast cancer and angina i year on.

Posts.Content: Love and hugs Peartree, the waiting is horrible.  Let's hope there's nothing to worry about.  Good luck, thinking of you, try to have a good Christmas, fingers crossed for a good result and a much better 2017.
Posts.Title: Please....not again

Posts.Content: I drank flat lemonade when I felt sick and gallons of coke zero when I didn't.  At the time I felt so ill I ate or drank whatever didn't make me feel worse so I practically lived off coke zero and caramel ice cream.  No wonder I lost weight!  I'm having a holiday in the UK with my lovely daughter and her family so I'll be putting a bit of weight on before I go back I expect! Love and hugs
Posts.Title: Can i drink lucozade on chemo

Posts.Content: Well done Lou, such good news about your NON angina!! . Hang in there for the next steps, you've done brilliantly!  Love and hugs
Posts.Title: Diagnosed with breast cancer and angina i year on.

Posts.Content: Hi Ladies,   I finished chemo T at end of August and still have problems with taste!  Getting better though so only way is up.  I had breathlessness and an increased heart rate from the end of the first T cycle as well as really bad fatigue (most days I couldn't lift my head off the pillow).  The breathing and heart problems were caused by really low potassium soI've now had 3 courses of potassium pills.  They caused a build up of fluid all down my left side so the potassium stuff was changed and back on the diuretic I take for high blood pressure.  Fine now except for swollen in my armpit due to rads but last one of those tomorrow.  Champagne on the menu tomorrow night!!! Still got some SEs le from chemo but not too bad and I know they'll continue for a while but heyho I'm still standing (new favourite song!) and still cheerful and positive!  I bought 3 Christmas presents yesterday - one for my sister and one each for the cats - every day has its laughs! Love and hugs
Posts.Title: 2nd T this week. How is everyone else doing ?

Posts.Content: I noticed yesterday a teeny weeny snow while fuzz appearing, I had my last chemo on 16 August so it's a sign that things are (slowly!) getting back to something approaching normal.  I was a dark ash blonde before but going grey that I coloured regularly.  I'll just have to see how I feel about white hair!  Love and hugs Wendy xxx
Posts.Title: 1st haircut after vhemo

Posts.Content: Hi Karen (Lacomtekp) I'm looking forward to Friday too!  I can imagine you're feeling a bit worried about Thursday but at least  we get the results immediately here, soby the time I see you you'll (hopefully) know everything's okay. Just had my hormone therapy consultation after a bone (DEXA?) scan and a blood test and I'm to be on Letrazole and vitamin D for the next 5 years unless I have nasty side effects, which were explained in detail!  Quite scary if you didn't read this forum regularly and know that everyone is different! See you Friday, love and hugs
Posts.Title: Parabens, etc

Posts.Content: Hi Ladies,  I'm a 38G and because of my age (72) very saggy.  I've only got one boob and it's really horrible if I'm not wearing some sort of support.  At the moment I'm wearing Triumph Doreen in a 38G and I don't look so lopsided if i hoik the good side up almost as tight as it will go and the prosthesis side as loose as it will go so both sides even up  They do come in more than black; white & beige, but I think it depends where you but them.I still look reasonably good in my beautiful Bravissimo bra but I can only wear it for a very short time as it's underwired and I worry about lymphodoema (spelling?).  There's no choice in France except for the catalogues or very expensive underwear shops and in any case rarely in my size.  I'm going to the UK on holiday in a couple of weeks and I'm going to try M&S and possibly Debenhams as well.  I wanted to try the new "magic wires" but they don't come in my size!  Love & hugs
Posts.Title: Mastectomy Bras!

Posts.Content: Hi London, I'm 73 and had a hysterectomy when I was 41.  Went on HRT straight after and stayed on it till I was 60 when my doctor said I'd gone past the menopause so didn't need it anymore.  Hot flushes, night sweats etc started almost immediately and thanks to letrazole I'm still getting them.  Only thing I've found that helps at all is a fan beside the settee and another one beside the bed. Drives my husband up the wall!  Don't know if that would help, no-one has offered me any medication, I'm just hoping they'll eventually stop.  Hope so as the slightest effort during the day causes me to sweat up so much my hair is wet - fan not much good when I'm sitting in a restaurant!  Sorry to moan when you've been through so much, I feel like a real wimp!  Lots of (hopefully not too sweaty) (((((()cwtchs))))))) love and hugs
Posts.Title: My Night....

Posts.Content: Hi Kismet, thanks, It's annoying that doctors don't seem to have made a link between this problem and letrazole.  It'll be interesting to see how many more of us there are.  I'm seeing my GP today to discuss the results of an xray on my knees and blood test because of severe joint pain so I'll mention it to her.  Love and hugs
Posts.Title: Eyes

Posts.Content: P.S. good luck with your chemo, it's no fun but it is doable! Hope it's not too horrible for you love and hugs
Posts.Title: Eyes

Posts.Content: I've used oil of Olay since I was a teenager (gosh, that's a long time ago!) and I've never had a problem with it.  It's not highly perfumed, goes on smoothly and is non-sticky.  Worth a try as it's not quite as expensive as some of the other creams.  Love and hugs
Posts.Title: Looking for a good light (thin) Moisturiser ?

Posts.Content: Hi all, another daft question but I'm hoping someone can answer it!  I know that chemo can cause vision blurring but does anyone know if it (or possibly letrazole) can cause floaters?  I've had little floaters for some years and was quite used them but I've now developed bigger ones in the last week or so. I'm trying to ignore them but it's really annoying!  I don't think there's any treatment but I'd just like to know the cause. Love and hugs
Posts.Title: Eyes

Posts.Content: Hi blipandme I don't live alone but I do have a not-to-well husband who is on oxygen 18 hrs a day so I really do sympathise.  I think the first thing is to give in to it as much as you need to and if you want to lie on the settee then do it!  There are lots of positives to being alone, but prepare for the bad days by having everything you might need close at hand such as drinks, comfort food, books and the TV remote! I've got two cats so I asked our local pharmacist what to and I now have a mask and a box of disposable plastic gloves which I can use if I need to do anything for them.  The other option is to contact your local vet and ask if he knows of a "hamster sitter" who could look after him while you are going through chemo. Best of luck,you know we're all rooting for you Lots of love and hugs Wendy xxx
Posts.Title: Living alone and having chemo

Posts.Content: Hi All, I haven't really regrown any underarm hair since it all fell out last April but I did feel a very slight crop a couple of days ago and used a man's disposable like I always have - no problems.  Bonus is I haven't needed deodorant since April either!  Just to make you all a bit jealous I have never had hair on my legs or arms so no need to worry about shaving, waxing or anything else.  Lucky me!!
Posts.Title: Under arm hair.......
